body:
kabhwan:

Since STORM-503 is old issue, and we already received several users suffering, it should be merged to all version branches.

I suffered this issue when I created binary dist file from current master and install manually. 
bin/storm script doesn't have permission for "execute".

githubbot:

Github user HeartSaVioR commented on the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/storm/pull/614#issuecomment-121767694

I suffered this issue when I created binary dist file and install manually.
bin/storm script doesn't have permission for "execute".

Sorry it may feel you off the topic, but recently I found elasticsearch-hadoop supports Storm officially which is maintained by Elastic.
https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-hadoop

I'd like to see a benefit to have this to Storm's external module instead of using Elastic's official module.
@sweetest Could you take a look at elasticsearch-hadoop?

If we're sure about the benefit, I also volunteer to be a sponsor, and take a look deeply.

Github user HeartSaVioR commented on the pull request:

I'd like to see a benefit to have this to Storm's external module instead of using Elastic's official module.

If we're sure about the benefit, I also volunteer to be a sponsor, and take a look deeply.
Elasticsearch-hadoop doesn't support Trident API now.

Yeah, right. My first look this PR seems superior than elasticsearch-hadoop.

Actually I'm thinking about future maintenance, where is the best place to improve Elasticsearch connector, Storm Project itself, or Elastic.
If we think elasticsearch-hadoop is more proper place, we can contribute elasticsearch-hadoop to improve. If we don't think, we can adopt this module and maintain it.

@sweetest If you don't mind, I'd like to hear your opinion. Thanks for contributing!

Now I'm not sure to know what happens.

I created binary dist file from master, 0.10.x-branch, 0.9.x-branch and extract it, and confirmed that bin/storm doesn't have permission for "execute" for the all branches.
(without applying this PR)

But when I download binary from storm official site, bin/storm has permission for "execute". I checked 0.10.0-beta1 and 0.9.5.

@caofangkun I'm sorry, but I admit I can't understand the situation and change my vote from +1 to +0. 
@ptgoetz Could you explain this situation, and take a look this PR?

ps. I'm using OSX 10.10.3 and maven 3.2.2.

STORM-643 KafkaUtils repeatedly fetches messages whose offset is out of range

$ git pull https://github.com/vesense/storm patch-2

Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:

To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch
with (at least) the following in the commit message:

arunmahadevan:

Agree with the approach of keeping data and txd id index in separate files.

Based on my understanding of transactional and opaque transactional spouts,

1. Transactional spout - (if same batch is re-emitted, it would contain the same tuples as before)

  • If we have seen the txn earlier and committed we can ignore this batch
  • If we have seen the txn earlier and not committed, we go to the txn offset and overwrite (to keep it simple).
    2. Opaque transactional spout - (same batch could be re-emitted with tuples having different values, which should override)
  • If we have seen the txn earlier, we need to overwrite from the txn start offset whether we have committed or not since the tuple values may have changed.

Hence if we get a txn where we have seen “preCommit”, we go to the start offset in the corresponding data file and start writing from that offset (which would handle both 1 & 2).

I think the third case where we get a txn id and the prev txn id is not committed ideally should not happen since trident guarantees that state updates would be ordered. (https://storm.apache.org/documentation/Trident-state).

revans2:

I agree that we need to overwrite, but the issue with overwrite is that HDFS is write once. Even append does not really work all that well in any version. So to overwrite we need to recover the successful data and delete the old file.
@alexshadow007 thanks for the fix.  I pulled this into master.
I forgot to formally say +1 so here it is.
+1 looks good to me.
Thanks @thilinarmtb I merged this into master.
Hmm, when I build it on my mac everything shows up fine, either with or without this fix. +1

revans2:

Thanks caofangkun,

I merged this into master.

@caofangkun I am a bit nervous about this change.  We are changing code that had the option to auto create parents or auto-delete parents to not have that option any more.  Yes this makes it simpler if you don't know if a directory was created or not, but it becomes a problem in the case of ACLs.  If we are running with security and we create a parent directory it may end up with the incorrect ACLs.

I would also want to see where each of these functions are called and see if they all have :force turned on or not.  If they do the parameter is unneeded.  If they do not I want to understand why they don't

githubbot:

Github user revans2 commented on the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/storm/pull/615#issuecomment-121968459

@caofangkun I am a bit nervous about this change. We are changing code that had the option to auto create parents or auto-delete parents to not have that option any more. Yes this makes it simpler if you don't know if a directory was created or not, but it becomes a problem in the case of ACLs. If we are running with security and we create a parent directory it may end up with the incorrect ACLs.

I would also want to see where each of these functions are called and see if they all have :force turned on or not. If they do the parameter is unneeded. If they do not I want to understand why they don't

Thanks @charleswhchan I merged this into master.
+1.  The only possible issue is if someone is implementing their own OutputCollector, possibly for running storm topologies on a different runtime. And I am not too concerned about breaking them.

revans2:

Thanks Sanket Reddy,

I merged this into master. Keep up the good work.

@chuanlei Sorry this has taken so long.  The change looks good to me.  +1

@HeartSaVioR I don't think we need a JIRA for this, it is a minor documentation change.

@sweetest The code looks great to me.  I would like to see some more javadocs explaining what each of the bolts/state do/need as input.  I would also like to see some javadocs around beginCommit and commit in the state explaining that adding a document to the search index is an idempotent operation so the commits can be ignored.

String propertiesFile, boolean envSub) throws IOException {

    }

    String propertiesFile, boolean envSub) throws IOException {
    -Yaml yaml = yaml();
    +
    InputStream in = FluxParser.class.getResourceAsStream(resource);

    +TopologyDef topology = parseInputStream(in, dumpYaml, processIncludes, propertiesFile, envSub);
    in.close();
    -if(dumpYaml){ - dumpYaml(topology, yaml); -}
  • if(processIncludes) { - return processIncludes(yaml, topology, propertiesFile, envSub); -}

    else

    { - return topology; -}

    +
    +return topology;
    }
    +
    + public static TopologyDef parseInputStream(InputStream inputStream, boolean dumpYaml, boolean processIncludes,
    + String propertiesFile, boolean envSub) throws IOException {
    +
    + Yaml yaml = yaml();
    +
    + if (inputStream == null) {

      • End diff –

@lyonbrw Indentation looks broken.

+1
@dossett do you want to file a JIRA for this?  It is not a big deal because it is such a small change, but it does impact what type of credit you get for your changes.  No JIRA currently means it does not show up in the change log.  Which usually is not a big deal for doc changes, but is slightly more important for code changes.
@chuanlei This is a rather interesting feature.  It would be nice if you could file a JIRA for this.

@lyonbrw
IMO it isn't a good way to close InputStream which is passed to a parameter. Caller can take care of it, and parseFile / parseResource already do it.
@HeartSaVioR Sounds good.  Thanks by the way for all of the reviews before becoming a committer.  We need more people to keep up with all of the pull requests.

@chuanlei 
We can get a hint from Heron paper that Twitter don't catch up latest Storm version.
Paper mentions ZeroMQ, but Storm changes default transport layer to Netty over one years ago.
It means that we should analyze that it still gives a benefit to Storm, and in my opinion you have to analyze it before posting pull request. 
Attaching performance test results is necessary.
Indentation fixed.

I merged this into 0.10.x-branch and 0.9.x-branch by cherry-picked.

Since there're different available sets of config validators among branches - master, 0.10.x, 0.9.x, I take the best proper validator to each branch.
- master: NotNullPosIntegerValidator
- 0.10.x: PositiveIntegerValidator
- 0.9.x: IntegerValidator
